Award.AwardTitle: 3D Visualization and Advanced Mapping Techniques for Metamorphic Terranes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Field geology is the foundation of the solid earth sciences but suffers from an image problem that stems in part from field geologists clinging to techniques and technology that have seen little change since the 19th century. Field geology is at the beginnings of a revolution, however, with the advent of new technologies that not only increase field efficiency but allow earth scientists to analyze problems that were impossibly complex in the past. Key to this developing revolution are three-dimensional (3D) visualization capabilities, and true 3D renderings that can be obtained from combinations of high resolution topography and high resolution photography draped on the terrain model. This study is exploring new techniques and workflows that are best suited to analyzing complex metamorphic structures using modern field computer capabilities and software. The study site is the west-central Panamint Mountains where a metamorphic complex is exposed over elevations ranging from near sea level to ~10,000 feet and surface conditions ranging from hyper-arid desert to moderately weathered rocks in open, sub-alpine forest. The study is evaluating different field workflows, beginning with a variant on conventional mapping techniques using Geographic Information System (GIS) field software supplemented with improved positional accuracy using laser ranging devices, limiting 3D visualization to an evening exercise tied to data backup and cleanup. This will be followed by experimentation with real-time, 3D field visualizations based on initial development of a high resolution digital elevation model (DEM) using a terrestrial laser scanner and completed with a real-time, in the field, 3D visualizations. Synergistic activities include using U-Pb geochronology to constrain the absolute age of deformation events, testing rock unit correlations through detrital zircon signature, and finite strain studies to aid kinematic interpretations.

This project has potential broader applications and implications for all field sciences with the potential to transform the way in which field studies are conducted. Although the project focus is on complex geologic structure, the techniques developed in the study will be exportable to a wider range of field projects in academia and industry. Digital mapping techniques are already seeing widespread application in a variety of fields but the present generations of methods are flat-map centric in a three-dimensional world. Moving to a true three-dimensional workflow should allow resolution of problems there were impossibly complex based on a flat-map workflow. Moreover, development of these techniques carries educational applications with the potential to allow accelerated learning of spatial concepts. To insure wide dissemination of project results the PI is conducting annual short courses in modern field techniques. The results of this study have the potential to profoundly impact that manner in which field sciences, including geologic mapping, are conducted and will thus be of significant value to the scientific community. In addition to the research goals, the project is supporting the training of students in STEM science at the graduate to undergraduate level at the University of Texas at El Paso. Given the university's demographics, the project will include students from underrepresented groups. The field studies in this project are entirely within Death Valley National Park, and the research products that will derive from this study will provide a resource for the National Park Service and will include outreach activities that will benefit the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at developing techniques and workflows using digital mapping technology to resolve three-dimensional (3D) structures in metamorphosed rocks, arguably the most difficult 3D visualization problem in geoscience.   In phase 1 this project developed a fully functional 2D mapping system based on the open source program QGIS.  As a broader impact we taught three short courses to professional geologists to expand access to this mapping system and we also use this system for teaching undergraduate field geology at UTEP, which puts students from underrepresented groups at the forefront of this technology.   In phase 2 we developed full 3D mapping methods through software and hardware experimentation using the Panamint Mountains of eastern California as a field test site.  In our initial experimentation with 3D mapping we acquired a terrestrial lidar data set (TLS) at three sites accessible by road or hiking trail, but shortly after these data were acquired it became clear that Structure from Motion/Multiview Stereo (SfM/MvS) methods were a superior, potentially transformative method for this study and we concentrated our efforts on these data.  The overlap between our TLS data and ground based SfM/MvS models allowed us to assess accuracy and precision of the SfM/MvS models as well as develop some initial techniques for 3D mapping (results reported in Pavlis and Mason, 2017; Fleming and Pavlis, in press, and Brush et al., in press).  A lesson from these publications applicable to a broader community is that systematic errors can arise in ground-based SfM/MvS data in steep terrain.  Specifically, although SfM/MvS models are generally scaled accurately, rigid body rotations are common, particularly where ground control placements, camera postions, or both contain only small variations in elevation relative to the elevation variations within the scene; a common scenario where the logistics of operating in steep terrain limits ground control placement and/or camera positions.  Given this problem Fleming and Pavlis (in press) developed a method for easily resolving this problem on virtual outcrops by using field orientation data compared to orientations measured on the virtual model and correcting the data with a single rigid body rotation.  At larger scales where models are hundreds to thousands of meter across this method is less robust, largely because the rigid body rotations are small, yet the rotations can produce a significant spatial error across the model.   Thus, more work is needed on this problem.

  The goal of developing procedures for 3D field mapping has been achieved (see attached images), but the ultimate goal of making this process straightforward and seamless has not.  At present, at least two complex software packages are required for 3D mapping and most mobile computers do not have sufficient resources for manipulating these large 3D data sets in the field, making it unlikely these techniques will be embraced quickly.   With present rapid advances in mobile computers and software, however, we anticipate that within 2-3 years our techniques can be applied directly, in the field, on SfM/MvS point clouds or TIN models (e.g. as described in Pavlis and Mason, 2017).  On the geologic applications side, the work to date has revealed unprecedented detail of the complex geologic structure of the Panamint Mountains, allowing us to both solve major problems and ask questions that would have been impossible without this technological revolution.  Our hope is that this project has laid the groundwork for future studies that fully involve 3D visualization and mapping in the field, potentially revolutionizing the foundation of geology, the mapping of geologic bodies as true 3D features.
